definitions: not having the ability to read or write in any language
showing lack of knowledge or education in a particular subject or area
examples: The illiterate population struggled to access government services
Many illiterate adults are now attending evening classes
His illiterate response revealed his unfamiliarity with scientific principles
She was financially illiterate despite her college degree

definitions: not following or based on the principles of logic or reason
going against what would be expected from rational thinking or common sense
examples: Her illogical argument confused everyone in the meeting
The illogical sequence of events made the story hard to follow
It seems illogical to refuse help when you need it
Their illogical decision cost the company millions

definitions: brightened with light from an artificial or natural source
decorated with gold, silver, and colored designs, especially in manuscripts
having achieved spiritual or intellectual enlightenment or understanding
examples: The illuminated building stood out against the night sky
Softly illuminated pathways guided visitors through the garden
The illuminated manuscript contained beautiful medieval artwork
An illuminated letter began each chapter of the book
His illuminated mind grasped complex philosophical concepts easily
She felt illuminated after years of meditation

definitions: giving off light or making something bright with light
helping to clarify or explain something by providing insight or information
examples: The illuminating glow of fireflies filled the summer evening
An illuminating lamp cast shadows on the wall
Her illuminating comments helped everyone understand the problem
The professor gave an illuminating lecture on quantum physics

definitions: based on or producing an illusion that deceives the senses
appearing real or true but actually false or not existing
examples: The illusory oasis disappeared as they got closer
Mirrors created an illusory sense of space
Their illusory profits vanished when properly audited
His illusory confidence masked deep insecurities

definitions: serving as an example or explanation to make something clear
containing or decorated with pictures, diagrams, or other visual representations
examples: These illustrative examples help students understand the concept
The illustrative case study demonstrated best practices
The illustrative guide included helpful diagrams and charts
An illustrative dictionary uses pictures to explain meanings

definitions: well known and respected for past achievements or high position
having earned fame and admiration through notable accomplishments
examples: The illustrious scientist won three Nobel prizes
She had an illustrious career spanning five decades
The illustrious alumni included presidents and CEOs
His illustrious ancestors founded the university

definitions: able to be thought of or formed as a mental image or concept
within the realm of what can be conceived or considered possible
examples: Every imaginable color decorated the festival grounds
They tried every imaginable solution to the problem
The worst imaginable outcome would be total system failure
This is the best imaginable result we could achieve

definitions: existing only in the mind or imagination, not in reality
relating to the square root of a negative number in mathematics
examples: Children often have imaginary friends during early childhood
The imaginary world in her novel felt incredibly real
The imaginary part of a complex number involves i
Students learned to plot imaginary numbers on graphs

definitions: having or showing the ability to form new ideas or images creatively
demonstrating original and creative thinking in design or execution
examples: The imaginative child created elaborate stories about dragons
An imaginative artist sees possibilities others miss
Her imaginative solution saved the company thousands
The imaginative design won international acclaim

definitions: not in a state of equilibrium or proper proportion physically
having an unequal or unfair distribution of parts, elements, or resources
examples: The imbalanced load caused the washing machine to shake
An imbalanced diet lacks essential nutrients
The imbalanced budget favored defense over education
Their imbalanced relationship caused constant conflicts

definitions: inspired or influenced thoroughly by a feeling, quality, or idea
permeated or saturated completely with a particular quality or substance
examples: The team was imbued with a strong sense of purpose
Her writing is imbued with deep compassion
The fabric was imbued with a pleasant lavender scent
The atmosphere was imbued with tension and uncertainty

definitions: made to copy or resemble something else, especially something genuine
made from artificial materials to look like something more valuable
examples: His imitation British accent fooled no one
The imitation artwork looked surprisingly authentic
She wore an imitation leather jacket to the concert
The imitation marble countertops were affordable

definitions: copying or following a model, especially in behavior or style
not original but rather derived from or based on something else
examples: Young children's imitative behavior helps them learn social skills
The imitative artist never developed his own style
Their imitative product design led to a lawsuit
The imitative architecture lacked originality

definitions: perfectly clean, neat, and tidy without any marks or mess
free from flaws, mistakes, or moral blemish of any kind
examples: Her immaculate kitchen sparkled after hours of cleaning
He always wore an immaculate white shirt
The immaculate performance earned a standing ovation
Her immaculate reputation remained untarnished

definitions: existing or operating within something as an inherent quality or essence
present throughout the universe as a divine or spiritual force
examples: The immanent contradictions in the theory became apparent
Beauty is immanent in nature itself
They believed in an immanent God present in all things
The immanent spirit guides all living beings

definitions: not relevant or important to the matter being considered
having no physical form or substance; spiritual rather than physical
examples: The exact time is immaterial to our discussion
Such minor details are immaterial to the outcome
Ghosts are said to be immaterial beings
The immaterial world of thoughts and ideas

definitions: not yet fully grown or developed physically or mentally
showing behavior more typical of someone younger; lacking emotional maturity
examples: The immature fruit was too sour to eat
Immature plants need protection from harsh weather
His immature response to criticism upset everyone
Such immature behavior is unexpected from a manager

definitions: too large, extensive, or extreme to be measured or calculated
so great in degree or extent that measurement becomes meaningless
examples: The immeasurable depths of the ocean remain unexplored
Time seemed immeasurable in the silent darkness
Her immeasurable kindness touched everyone she met
The loss caused immeasurable grief to the family

definitions: occurring or done at once without any delay or interval
nearest in time, space, or relationship; next to or very close
having no intervening medium, agent, or influence; direct
examples: The immediate response saved many lives
We need immediate medical attention here
The immediate area was evacuated for safety
His immediate family attended the private ceremony
The immediate cause of failure was overheating
There's no immediate connection between these events

definitions: extending back beyond memory, record, or knowledge; ancient beyond remembrance
examples: This tradition has existed since time immemorial
The immemorial customs of the indigenous people
From time immemorial, humans have gazed at stars
These immemorial hills have witnessed countless generations

definitions: extremely large or great in size, scale, or extent
very great in degree, intensity, or amount; tremendous
examples: The immense building dominated the city skyline
An immense crowd gathered for the celebration
She felt immense relief when the test ended
The project required immense concentration and effort

definitions: about to happen very soon; impending and likely to occur at any moment
examples: The storm's arrival appeared imminent as clouds darkened
Imminent danger forced them to evacuate immediately
Her imminent departure saddened her colleagues
Signs pointed to imminent economic collapse

definitions: unable to move or be moved due to injury, disability, or restraint
not moving; staying completely still and motionless
examples: The accident left him immobile for several months
The immobile patient required constant care
She remained immobile, hoping the bear wouldn't notice her
The immobile statue stood for centuries

definitions: not conforming to accepted standards of morality or ethical behavior
not conforming to accepted standards of sexual behavior or propriety
examples: Many consider tax evasion an immoral act
The immoral treatment of prisoners sparked protests
Victorian society condemned immoral relationships harshly
The book was banned for immoral content

definitions: living forever; never dying or decaying; having eternal life
deserving to be remembered forever; having lasting fame
examples: Greek myths tell of immortal gods on Olympus
Scientists search for ways to become immortal
Shakespeare's immortal words inspire readers today
Her immortal performance became legendary

definitions: incapable of being moved physically; fixed firmly in place
not able to be changed or persuaded; steadfast and resolute
examples: The immovable boulder blocked the mountain path
These immovable fixtures are part of the building
She remained immovable in her decision to resign
His immovable stance frustrated negotiators

definitions: protected against a particular disease by natural resistance or vaccination
not affected by or subject to something, especially something undesirable
examples: Vaccinated children are immune to measles
Some people are naturally immune to certain viruses
No one is immune from criticism
The wealthy seemed immune to economic hardship

definitions: relating to the branch of medicine and biology concerned with immunity and immune responses
examples: The immunological response varied between patients
Advanced immunological research offers hope for cancer treatment
Her immunological system was compromised by stress
The immunological markers indicated an infection

definitions: unchanging over time or unable to be changed; permanent and unalterable
examples: The laws of physics are immutable
Death remains an immutable fact of life
His immutable principles guided every decision
The contract's immutable terms couldn't be renegotiated

definitions: strongly affected or influenced by something, usually negatively
pressed firmly together or wedged in position, especially of teeth
examples: Communities impacted by flooding need immediate aid
The impacted regions struggled to recover
The impacted wisdom tooth required surgical removal
Impacted earwax caused temporary hearing loss

definitions: weakened, damaged, or diminished in function or ability
having a disability or reduced function in a specific area
examples: His impaired judgment led to poor decisions
The accident left her with impaired mobility
Visually impaired students use special software
The hearing impaired community uses sign language

definitions: treating all rivals or disputants equally; not partial or biased toward any side
examples: An impartial judge must hear both sides fairly
The impartial investigation revealed surprising facts
We need an impartial mediator for this dispute
Her impartial analysis impressed everyone

definitions: impossible to travel along or through due to obstacles or conditions
impossible to overcome or get past; insurmountable
examples: Snow made the mountain road impassable
The impassable jungle deterred most explorers
The impassable gulf between their views ended negotiations
An impassable barrier stood between them

definitions: filled with or showing great emotion, passion, or fervor about something
examples: Her impassioned speech moved the audience to tears
The lawyer made an impassioned plea for mercy
His impassioned defense of freedom inspired millions
The impassioned debate lasted for hours

definitions: having or showing a tendency to be quickly irritated or provoked
restlessly eager for something to happen or arrive
examples: The impatient customer complained about the slow service
Don't be impatient with children learning to read
She was impatient for the results to arrive
The impatient crowd waited for the concert

definitions: in accordance with the highest standards; faultless and perfect in every way
examples: Her impeccable manners impressed the royal family
The restaurant's impeccable service earned five stars
His impeccable timing saved the company
She has impeccable taste in fashion

definitions: delayed, obstructed, or prevented from making progress or movement
examples: Traffic was impeded by the fallen tree
His impeded speech made communication difficult
Progress was impeded by bureaucratic red tape
The impeded flow caused the pipe to burst

definitions: actively delaying or preventing progress, movement, or action
examples: The impeding regulations slowed development
Impeding traffic is a serious offense
The impeding factors must be addressed immediately
Stop impeding our efforts to improve

definitions: urged, driven, or forced to do something by a strong motivation or force
examples: She felt impelled to speak out against injustice
Impelled by curiosity, he opened the mysterious door
They were impelled forward by the crowd
He seemed impelled by forces beyond his control

definitions: about to happen soon, especially something unpleasant or momentous
examples: The impending storm forced event cancellations
Signs of impending disaster were everywhere
Their impending marriage excited both families
The impending deadline created stress

definitions: impossible to pass through or enter due to density or hardness
impossible to understand or discern; incomprehensible
examples: The impenetrable fortress withstood every attack
An impenetrable wall of thorns blocked the path
Her impenetrable expression revealed nothing
The document's impenetrable jargon confused readers

definitions: of vital importance; absolutely necessary or required
giving an authoritative command; expressing a command
examples: It's imperative that we leave immediately
Imperative safety measures saved lives
She spoke in an imperative tone
The imperative mood expresses commands

definitions: so slight, gradual, or subtle as not to be perceived by the senses
examples: The change was almost imperceptible at first
An imperceptible shift in tone worried him
The imperceptible movement caught the camera
Her imperceptible nod signaled agreement

definitions: not perfect; having faults, defects, or shortcomings
denoting a tense of verbs expressing incomplete or continuing action
examples: We live in an imperfect world
The imperfect diamond was still beautiful
The imperfect tense describes ongoing past actions
Spanish uses the imperfect for habitual actions

definitions: relating to an empire, emperor, or supreme ruler
magnificent, majestic, or befitting an emperor; commanding
examples: The imperial palace housed countless treasures
Imperial Rome controlled vast territories
She spoke with an imperial tone of authority
His imperial manner intimidated subordinates

definitions: relating to or supporting a policy of extending power through colonization
examples: The imperialist powers divided Africa among themselves
Imperialist policies faced growing opposition
His imperialist ambitions threatened regional stability
The imperialist mindset justified exploitation

definitions: relating to or characterized by imperialism or imperial ambitions
examples: Their imperialistic foreign policy sparked protests
Imperialistic attitudes persisted after independence
The company's imperialistic expansion worried competitors
His imperialistic behavior alienated allies

definitions: assuming power or authority without justification; arrogant and domineering
examples: Her imperious demands exhausted the staff
The imperious executive ignored all advice
He gave an imperious wave of dismissal
The cat's imperious stare demanded attention

definitions: not allowing fluid to pass through; preventing penetration by liquids or gases
examples: The impermeable membrane kept moisture out
Impermeable rock layers trap groundwater
An impermeable barrier protected the electronics
The impermeable coating prevented rust
